title: usb dead after download direct from net?

forumNotes.author: betrand
forumNotes.content:
My stick is no longer bootable, recognized, or anything.  
The only thing is, in Windows (xp), you still see the  
clickable icon of the drive. Dbl clic. Please insert drive in (letter).  
-So at the moment is acting (or seen) like a hub,  
waiting for some 'disk space' to be inserted.  
(I mean, is the above the way a usb drive works, ie in two parts?)  

But my real question..  
I have knowledge of the existence of usb write filter,  
ewf, though I thought for now I'd be ok.   
I think my problem is, When I copy a file from Pc hdd to usb stick, everything fine.  
When I download direct the file (.html, .zip) from internet, my sticks appear to have  
had problems, even disapearing.  
I downloaded htmls \&zips direct, yesterday. Today ok, +Icopied the said files to hdd,  
but then took out the (bootable)usb from computer, and in other computer, no boot.  
Opened in drive hex editor, wrong cylinder count or somthing, so not able to see any hex.  
Testdisk, too, but drive not even in selection menu. Hum.. It is dead, isn't it?  

Is there a tool or a method on what to do with a dead usb? (tap it against something, open-it, blow on it with love)  
I will google.  
Maybe there are other factors too.   
Thank you.

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> It is dead, isn't it? Possibly ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif), but not necessarily ![:dubbio:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/dubbio.gif). > Is there a tool or a method on what to do with a dead usb? (tap it against something, open-it, blow on it with love) If you whistle to it ***softly*** Yankee Doodle Dandy ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) it may be revived, but there are very few evidences of this to have ever happened, actual experiments never managed to find the right low, humming tone needed. ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) ...the "tap it against something" is a nice one! ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) :wink: It is possible - though NOT probable, that a full reset may revive it. Here: [http://www.msfn.org/...up-a-usb-drive/](http://www.msfn.org/board/topic/137990-i-screwed-up-a-usb-drive/ "External link") you can find an example of the procedure involved. Very low possibilities, but probably still worth a try. Please take note that even if successful, resetting the stick will delete permanently any and all data that may still be recoverable. If you need to recover files from it, you need to stop now and ask a professional.
![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: steve6375
forumNotes.content: RMPrepUSB will clean and reformat the stick. But I suspect you may have a 'fake' one. Test it with the Quick Size Test button in RMPrepUSB (destroys all data) to see if it is OK.

> Ok, > > Ut165 up and running, info (printscreens) is the same as on msfn link. > Having trouble finding Beeblebox, as sourcefouge= .jar file, + cant find dll in same folder. > and site archive of students..etcetc/beeblebroxsetup.zip= the setup doesn't setup. > @ steve6375, I Will try RMPrepUSB at some point. My version of the program doesn't have an f10. > Or maybe it does but there is something I don't know. > cheers. Well, it seems to me like you jumped a bit: which PID and VID does Chipgenius find? You need this data in order to hopefully find here: [http://flashboot.ru/...php?name=iflash](http://flashboot.ru/index.php?name=iflash "External link") the "right" program. This should work: [http://web.archive.o...broxntsetup.zip](http://web.archive.org/web/20060223003044/students.cs.byu.edu/~codyb/beeblebroxntsetup.zip "External link") but you don't actually \*need\* it, it was just an example, you can use Tiny Hexer or almost anything else that can open a \\\\.\\PhysicalDrive, it is only to verify it is accessible at that level.
:smile: Wonko

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> Oups, missed that:  
> Well, it seems to me like you jumped a bit: which PID and VID does Chipgenius find?  
> 0C76 0005  
This should mean that you have a SSS controller (and NOT an USBest).  
The relevant tool should be one of this "family":  
[http://www.flashboot...es\&op=cat\&id=17](http://www.flashboot.ru/index.php?name=Files&op=cat&id=17 "External link")  
Does Chipgenius give you additional info on the actual controller?  
Like SSS686, SSS690, etc.?  

Any way, BEFORE trying the actual MPTool, I would try the ERASE Utility one:  
[http://www.flashboot...s-file-326.html](http://www.flashboot.ru/Files-file-326.html "External link")  

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  
Wonko

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> Ehere do I go from there , > is the Ut tool only for usbest controller, or can SSS function too? Are you joking or what? ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) If it wasn't clear previously and to the benefit of future readers of this thread ![:worship:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/worship.gif): * We are talking of MANUFACTURER tools, NOT "generic" software.
* The USBest tool(s) are for USBest controllers. (and obviously ONLY for them) * The SSS tool(s) are for SSS controllers. (and obviously ONLY for them) * More generally the ***xyz*** tool(s) are for ***xyz*** controllers. (and obviously ONLY for them)
NEVER, and when I say NEVER, I do mean ***NEVER*** attempt using a Manufacturer tool on *another Manufacturer chip* or to force it's use (unless you REALLY know where your towel is). ![:yahoo:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/yahoo.gif) Further, better worded advice: [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=14564](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=14564 "External link") starting here: [http://www.911cd.net...pic=14564\&st=15](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=14564&st=15 "External link")
![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif) Wonko

forumNotes.author: Wonko the Sane
forumNotes.content:
> Thanks, Wonko.   
You are welcome ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif), though really I thought that the general idea was clear enough from the beginning.![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  

I'll try to re-cap (again for the benefit of future readers).  

You are going to use a "Manufacturer tool", a specific software that is used in factory to initialize the USB stick.  

First step is to identify the Manufacturer, the Chipgenius tool is a good one to do so:  
<http://reboot.pro/4661/>  
as it often provides besides the needed VID and PID of the device, the name of the Manufacturer and in some cases also the actual Controller model (or family of models).  

In this case:  
> PnP Device ID: VID = 0C76 PID = 0005

With the above info you go here:  
[http://flashboot.ru/...php?name=iflash](http://flashboot.ru/index.php?name=iflash "External link")  
and enter the VID and PID in the correspondent textboxes and click on the Найти (Найти=Find) button.  

The result will be all entries that match given VID and PID.  

If you are lucky, you will find one or more entries with (on the left) the actual description of your model of USB stick and on the right the name of the tool (and hopefully a link to it).  

Please note how there is NOT an univocal correspondence between VID/PID and actual controller, and as in the case discusse here, the additional info given by Chipgenius is useful:  
> Chip Vendor: SSS  
> Chip Part-Number: SSS6677/SSS6690

Still following this example, one of the entries with a link leads you here:  
[http://www.flashboot...s-file-329.html](http://www.flashboot.ru/Files-file-329.html "External link")  

In this page at the top there is a "SSS (Solid State System)" text that is actually a link to the whole directory:  
[http://www.flashboot...es\&op=cat\&id=17](http://www.flashboot.ru/index.php?name=Files&op=cat&id=17 "External link")  
of SSS related tools.  

Among these, you will have to do some tests to find the one (or more than one) that are suitable for your USB stick.  

There are often several different versions of the same utility, not necessarily "latest" is the best one, and often an "older" version may contain a help file or some instructions, or a readme.txt about the usage.  

Additionally by using Google translate, you can usually understand enough from the user posts - that in some cases offer help with the usage, in this case also an "older" version will likely have more comments and it is more likely to be found in them some useful info on the usage.  

Also, the same Manufacturer may have different utilities for different scopes, so you need some time and patience (and usually a lot of ***guessing*** ![:w00t:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/w00t.gif)) in order to find the "right" tool, and to find the "right" way to use it. ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png)   

Keep in mind that these are very specific tools made for engineers that need not (or like to think they need not ![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)) instructions to use such tools.  

At a certain point you will need to choose, and the only recommendation I can give you is: ![:blink:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/blink.png)   
[http://www.imdb.com/...uotes?qt0357926](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0097576/quotes?qt0357926 "External link")  
> **Grail Knight:** But choose wisely, for while the true Grail will bring you life, the false Grail will take it from you.

![:cheers:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/cheers.gif)  
Wonko
